Dear Ms. Aufdemberge:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
January 6, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when
specified by rule.
Two of thirteen new staff did not have verification of
completion of high school or a GED prior to being hired.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
Nine of seventeen staff were missing either a 90-day or
annual performance evaluation for 2021.
(Repeat violation from Interim 2020 with approved CAP on
01/25/2021)
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(1) The licensee shall provide an orientation program for new
employees. Job shadowing shall not be the only form of
orientation. The orientation shall include the following:
(a) The institution's purpose, policies, and procedures,
including discipline, crisis intervention techniques, and
emergency and safety procedures.
4

While there was some evidence that new staff were
oriented, seven of thirteen staff were missing the document
that verifies it (Orientation Training Guide).
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(3) The licensee shall document that each staff person whose
function is covered by these rules has participated in a minimum
of 50 clock hours of planned training within the first year of
employment and a minimum of 25 clock hours of training
annually thereafter related to the employee’s job function. At
least 16 of the 50 hours provided in the first year shall be
orientation provided prior to the assumption of duties.
Two of four employee files did not have a minimum of 25
hours of training annually in 2021.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(c) A brief description of the resident's preparation for
placement and general physical and emotional state at the time
of admission.
Three of three youth files did not describe how Vista Maria
staff prepared them on the day of admission. One intake
worker described how another agency may have prepared
the youth prior to placement at Vista. A second intake
worker indicated the youth was interviewed and would be
oriented but does not orient youth herself. A third intake
worker left this section blank.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not
be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
5

RFCAN 2.10 Planned Discharge Medication (DHHS – 5921
pg 27 updated 3/21)
Four of six discharge medication forms were not
signed by the person to whom the youth was
discharged.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
To assure future compliance with discharge rules and contracts, I recommended
DHHS – form 5921 completed by Health Services and the two-page client discharge
form completed by the social services worker and supervisor be attached and placed
together in the file. Both forms should be signed by the person receiving the
discharged youth.
V. CONSULTATION
Re: Rule 152 (c) cited above, the actual staff person who orients the youth to her
living quarters (i.e., tour of building, introductions, bedroom, youth handbook,
therapist, etc.) should be the person who documents this on the Client Information
form on the day of admission.
6

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse during this licensing period.
In this investigation the facility was cited when a staff person physically pulled a youth
and was subsequently deemed unsuitable to work with children. The corrective
action plan included terminating the staff’s employment.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
This investigation involved a staff person using improper restraint techniques and
inappropriate discipline. That staff person was terminated.
The facility submitted one acceptable corrective action plan unrelated to maltreatment
during this licensing period.
This investigation involved the facility being cited for improper restraint after a staff
person failed to follow the physical management techniques established at the
facility. The corrective action included a review of the restraint and staff role plays at
an all-staff meeting.
At the Interim inspection of 2020, Vista Maria Mental Health was cited for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records (j)
Finally, Vista Maria Mental Health plans to renovate Rose Hall to add calming rooms
and family activity rooms. The youth residing in Rose Hall will be moved to other
buildings on campus during this time. The renovation is expected to be completed in
May 2022.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MSA requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
